review_title: Nice community and a good work pace with plenty of variety

cons: Limited opportunity for progression as the department is relatively small.

cons: No major issues with employer.

review_title: Better avoided: University of the Year? Better call it the Sham of the Year!
pros: Amazing campus and some genuinely nice people! Nice working atmosphere in some areas.
cons:
Several departments have incredibly bad environment with a clear segregation between buddies and non-buddies, toxic atmosphere, and inexcusable episodes of bullying that seem to perpetuate across the years with no consequences for leadership. 

I know of several foreign staff members that complained about feeling particularly unwelcome and who were asked why they didn't go back to their own countries. There is no excuse for this type of behaviour in the UK!

Despite its modern-looking campus and some forward-thinking people, this is an incredibly parochial institution. Research is perceived by many people higher-up and across the institution as a nuisance that shouldn't be allocated too much time. Teaching is truly the only priority, as the main income generator, with some money seemingly spent on research to tick the necessary boxes for Ref and ranking purposes or to be able to inaugurate some fancy new building on campus and show off.

There seems to be a no-accountability policy in place where heads of several department shamelessly hire and promote friends, lovers,  and family with no questions asked and little regard for criteria or merit. I'm surprised that these seem to go unchecked.

pros: .Great company to work for
cons: Salary isn't the best could be better

review_title: Excellent - unless you're not part of the clique
pros: Beautiful campus, great work-life balance activities for free for all staff, lots of ongoing training, standard office hours, generally nice people to work with.
cons:
It's a clique. Everyone's related to each other! And if they're not related, they know each other. Whilst this can be great fun, all it takes is for one person to take offence with you and the whole attitude changes. Most people are supportive and you can have a laugh with them but beware of what you say because there will always be someone within earshot who will twist your words and pass their version on to someone else.

Also beware that the place is run on temporary/casual staff from agencies and that permanent jobs are very often given to people who already work inside the company. Although this is good if someone's been temping and gets a permanent job, it can mean that current employees become sullen if an 'outsider' gets a job they applied for. 

In summary, it really does depend on who you work with and get on with. You're either part of the clique or an 'outsider', unfortunately.
